text:
Make Your UI Stand Out with the 60-30-10 Rule üèÜ

What is the 60-30-10 rule?

One of the most effective and timeless principles in UI design is the 60-30-10 rule. This approach helps create visually appealing, balanced, and cohesive designs that guide users' eyes where they need to go. Here's how it works:

üîπ 60% Primary Color: Sets the overall tone and covers large areas, like backgrounds or primary components. This main color serves as the foundation of the design.

üîπ 30% Secondary Color: Adds contrast and brings interest without overwhelming the dominant color. Think menus, buttons, or secondary elements.

üîπ 10% Accent Color: The attention-grabber. Used sparingly, this color highlights crucial elements like call-to-action buttons or icons, guiding users to key interactions.

By following this rule, you create a design that feels both structured and engaging, ensuring a smooth user experience that doesn't overwhelm the eye. Want your UI to stand out? Let the 60-30-10 rule lead the way!

Is the Role of Wireframes Still Vital in 2024?

The answer is...

Yes, wireframes are still used for creating the foundation of a design. Here's why:

‚Ä¢ Clear Structure: They provide a simplified layout, allowing designers to focus on the basic structure and flow.

‚Ä¢ Focus on Usability: Wireframes emphasize user interaction and functionality before getting into visual details like colors or fonts.

‚Ä¢ Efficient Communication: They help communicate ideas clearly between designers, developers, and stakeholders.

‚Ä¢ Faster Iteration: It's easier to make changes at the wireframe stage, saving time during the later design phases.

‚Ä¢ Better Problem Solving: Wireframes help identify potential design and usability issues early in the process.

However, with the rise of design tools that allow rapid prototyping, some designers may skip traditional wireframing and jump straight into high-fidelity mockups or interactive prototypes. It depends on the project, timeline, and the team's workflow. But overall, wireframes remain an effective way to ensure the design's foundation is solid before diving into the more polished stages.

üèÜ Pro tips: if your project time period is not long enough, you can create the wireframes for important pages (eg. landing page) & skip it for less important pages (eg. notification page).

üìå What's the impact of wireframes in your design journey? Let me know in comments (Very curious to knowüßê)

0 to 2,000,000+ impressions on LinkedIn in just 3 months!!ü§Ø

üèÜ You can also achieve this milestone. here's the lowdown on how to get your content SEEN in 3 simple steps:

üîë Hook is the Key: Craft an eye-catching question or statement that makes people STOP and WANT to read more. (Think: bold claims, surprising stats, or relatable problems.)

üëë Content is king (or queen): Share valuable, engaging posts. Use a mix of formats (text, images, videos) to keep things interesting. Focus on providing insights, tips, or sparking discussions in your industry.

üó£Ô∏è Engage, engage, engage: Don't just post and disappear. Respond to comments, participate in conversations, and share other people's content you find interesting. The more you interact, the more people will see you.

üèÖBonus tip: Be consistent! The LinkedIn algorithm rewards those who show up regularly. Aim for a few high-quality posts per week.

Design is not only About Visual Aesthetics üé®

When we talk about UI/UX, it's easy to think only of the visuals. But there's so much more it brings to the table! Here's a look at four powerful impacts of great design:

‚Ä¢ Better User Experiences
UI/UX isn't just about meeting user needs‚Äîit's about deeply understanding them, making each interaction simple, seamless, and enjoyable.

‚Ä¢ Increased Conversions
A smooth, intuitive experience makes it easy for users to take action, improving conversion rates and boosting business value.

‚Ä¢ Emotional Connections
Engaging, human-centered design goes beyond transactions, creating meaningful connections that foster brand loyalty.

‚Ä¢ Data-Driven Decisions
With UX research and testing, design becomes a powerful, insight-driven process, helping us tailor experiences to real user behavior.

UI/UX is a game-changer, driving success by combining function, emotion, and purpose.

üí¨ How has design transformed your product or service?

Everything You Need to Know About Customer Experience (CX) üßê

What is CX?

CX or Customer Experience is the overall perception customers have of a brand through their entire journey‚Äîfrom initial awareness to post-purchase interactions. It's about how customers feel at every touchpoint with a brand, whether they're browsing the website, contacting support, or interacting on social media. Here are some key elements of CX:

‚Ä¢ Customer satisfaction: How satisfied customers are with a product or service.

‚Ä¢ Customer relationship management (CRM): How a company interacts with customers.

‚Ä¢ Emotional Connection: What customers feel after interacting with your brand.

‚Ä¢ Feedback: Creating effective channels for customers to share their thoughts.

‚Ä¢ Personalization: Does the brand feel tailored to each customer?

What is the Relation Between CX and UX?

UX or User Experience is a core part of CX. While CX covers the full customer journey, UX focuses specifically on user interaction with a product or service. A great UX within a product makes a positive contribution to the overall CX, but CX goes beyond that, involving support, brand engagement, and customer satisfaction.

Great CX is built on more than just a great product; it's about consistent, meaningful interactions that make customers feel valued and understood. Invest in both UX design and CX strategy to create memorable, loyal customer relationships.

How to use colours for indications? ü§î

Let's understand with examples ‚ú®

Ever filled out a form and gotten a cryptic error message?
Or clicked "submit" only to be met with a confusing yellow warning?
Colors in UI/UX design are more than just aesthetics - they're silent communicators, guiding users through your interface.üîç

Here's the color psychology cheat sheet you NEED to bookmark:

Red: Stop üõë - It screams errors, danger, and prompts immediate attention. Use it sparingly for critical issues.

Yellow: Caution ‚ö†Ô∏è - Think "proceed with awareness." Use it for warnings or highlighting important information.

Blue: Information ‚ÑπÔ∏è - Cool and calming, blue is perfect for general notifications and links.

Green: Success! ‚úÖ - Green conveys accomplishment and a positive outcome. Use it for completed tasks and positive feedback.

üèÖBonus Tip: Be culturally aware! Colors can have different meanings in various cultures. Always research your target audience.

Let's discuss!
